title: Add setup commands to install pip3/conda when needed
body:
Azure A100 VM requires the ubuntu hpc image where pip3/conda are not installed.
To fix this I add commands in the yaml template to install pip3/conda when needed.

title: Build and upload wheels to cluster
body: This PR enables build and upload wheels to cluster for both users and developers. The CI is now running without editable mode.

I feel like the `getting-started` part could be the most important part to get the first few users. We may need to take some time reading it together and make it extremely simple and clear for the new users.

title: It is possible to `sky stop` a cluster that is in 'INIT' state
body:
`sky cpunode`, then Ctrl+C before provision finishes (get Aborted! message)

Now there's a cluster in `sky status` table in `INIT` state. Running `sky stop` puts it in the `STOPPED` state. This should not happen since the cluster doesn't exist.

title: Remove capture_output to maintain py3.6 support
body: Closes #329 by redirecting output to devnull instead of using capture_output.

title: Incompatible python api calls
body:
For example, `capture_output` is only supported by python3.7. But our codebase assumes python>=3.6. https://github.com/concretevitamin/sky-experiments/blob/cf3f5c0d90e38791fe0961ecbb21625ab00d2f02/prototype/sky/backends/backend_utils.py#L766

https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html

We can either enforce using python>=3.7, or we can carefully check if our code is using 3.7+ features.

title: Initializing Azure instances is very slow
body:
It takes me 14min to spin up a cluster with 2 cpu nodes.

The most time consuming part is installing pip packages, especially `azure-cli`. This may be addressed by releasing images with `azure-cli` pre-installed.

title: Keep wheels build up-to-date
body:
Actual testing is by manually launching and ssh into the cluster to see if the installed sky get updated.

A simplified testing procedure:

1. Under the directory containing `setup.py`, run `pip wheel --no-deps . --wheel-dir /tmp`. This generates the wheel `/tmp/sky-*.whl`
2. Use `unzip` command to see the content of the wheel.
3. Delete `build` in the current directory, the wheel and unzipped files in `/tmp`
4. Update your code, repeat 1-2 to see if the content in the wheel includes updated code.

Closes #296
Closes #260

title: file_mount -> Storage shorthand for YAMLs and docs
body:
This PR adds a shorthand for users to directly use file_mounts to create and mount sky.Storage objects. This makes the YAML less wordy for most users. For power users, the declarative `storage` and `storage_mount` specification is still supported.

```yaml
file_mounts:
  # This uses rsync to directly copy files from your machine to the remote VM.
  /datasets: ~/datasets

  # This uses sky Storage to first create a S3 bucket named sky-dataset,
  # copies the contents of ~/datasets to the remote bucket and makes the
  # bucket persistent (i.e., the bucket is not deleted after the completion of
  # this sky task, and future invocations of this bucket will be much faster).
  # The bucket is mounted at /datasets-storage.
  /datasets-storage:
    name: sky-dataset
    source: ~/datasets
    force_stores: [s3] # Could be [s3, gcs], [gcs] default: None
    persistent: True  # Defaults to True, can be set to false.

  # This re-uses a predefined bucket (sky-dataset, defined above) and mounts it
  # directly at /datasets-s3.
  /datasets-s3: s3://sky-dataset
```

A demo is included in `examples/storage_demo.yaml`

title: Inconsistent Python versions on Azure
body:
When starting Azure with 2 cpu nodes, autoscaler failed to spin up the worker node because:

```
  File "/anaconda/envs/py38_default/lib/python3.8/site-packages/ray/_private/services.py", line 809, in check_version_info
    raise RuntimeError(error_message)
RuntimeError: Version mismatch: The cluster was started with:
    Ray: 1.9.2
    Python: 3.8.12
This process on node 10.43.0.14 was started with:
    Ray: 1.9.2
    Python: 3.8.11
```

This is because different base images are being used:

title: Problem with Gcloud authentication

Main changes:

2. Update the `worker.py` from v1.10

title: Sky down not working for stopped GCP
body:
Ray is buggy for deleting stopped clusters of all clouds. We call the `awscli` for AWS to solve the problem. For now we just skip the stopped GCP clusters during terminating, we need to support deleting them as well.

To repro
```bash
sky launch --cloud GCP -c debug examples/minimal.yaml           

# Wait until UI changes from Stopping to Stopped.
sky stop debug

# This has no actual effect, as seen in the AWS UI -- cluster remains in Stopped.
# `sky status` removed the cluster entry, so it is now leaked.
sky down debug
```

title: Consider allowing users to configure cloud templates / changing GCP's project_id
body:
(To discuss) Motivations for configurability of cloud templates
- (GCP) users may want to change GCP's project id
- (Azure) similarly, subscriptions etc.
- Users may want to add disks

Downsides of exposing the templates
- Too much control; e.g.,
  - users can mess with the setup commands
  - users can add heterogeneous type clusters, but sky itself doesn't have this notion (yet), which may lead to bugs
We could "mitigate" by saying modify at your own risk.
-----------

Main motivation: some pilot users use GCP.  For this specific use case we can do away with configurability: the system can grab the local default project_id and fill it into the cluster template:
```
gcloud config get-value project 2>/dev/null
```

title: Terminate stopped instance for aws
body:
> After looking into the code of ray, it seems like the problem comes from this [line](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/7f1bacc7dc9caf6d0ec042e39499bbf1d9a7d065/python/ray/autoscaler/_private/commands.py#L424), where the `provider.non_terminated_nodes()` only returns nodes that are `running` or `pending` ignoring those in `stopped` or `stopping` status.

Using the aws cli and the region information from our cluster config, we can now terminate the stopped aws instance.

title: Fix the hanging problem with `sky start`
body: This PR solves the problem in #205, by reducing the retry times for boto3 for AWS (retry times: 12 -> 5). 12 is the default number defined in ray, and 5 is the default number defined by awscli. Previously, it hangs for a very long time (about 40min) when insufficient capacity occurs during `sky start`. The reason for that is the time for retry increases exponentially. [reference](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/276ff2b7eda27b2e16c9f16da887a9e861112459/python/ray/autoscaler/_private/constants.py#L68)

title: Add tests with mocked clouds
body: We can consider adding tests with mocked clouds (e.g. `moto` for aws) as ray does [here](https://github.com/ray-project/ray/blob/7f1bacc7dc9caf6d0ec042e39499bbf1d9a7d065/python/ray/tests/test_cli.py#L255).

title: Multi-node ray.tune can only be run in default python
body: Our current implementation only allows `ray.tune` to be run in the ray cluster started by sky, since ray is not robust to have two ray clusters running on multiple nodes. That forces the program to use the default python version (in AWS, python=3.6.9) and cannot constraint the resources used by the `ray.tune`, which is not ideal. This can be easier to solve when we adopt better task packaging, e.g. using docker.

title: Use a consistent linter
body: The linter often generates different formats for my local files, causing tons of linting errors in CI, making me very sad. Also our linter does not enforce strict format, that is you can have multiple formats that can pass the linter, and it is not clear which is the right one. We may use a different linter, as the discussion in ray: https://github.com/ray-project/ray/pull/21975

title: Fix the default image on Azure for K80/A100
body:
Our current default image used in Azure fails on K80 (our gpunode) and A100 due to the below reasons.
K80: `HyperVGenerations` mismatched
A100: cuda driver mismatched

This PR addresses this issue with correct image (Azure HPC) and generation version.

See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/nda100-v4-series
> Due to increased GPU memory I/O footprint, the ND A100 v4 requires the use of [Generation 2 VMs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/generation-2) and marketplace images. The [Azure HPC images](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/hpc/configure) are strongly recommended. Azure HPC Ubuntu 18.04, 20.04 and Azure HPC CentOS 7.9 images are supported.

Also `HyperVGenerations` in https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/nc-series

title: `sky launch` with different setup command on multi-node will not run new setup on worker nodes
body: `sky launch` for a multi-node cluster with a different `setup.sh` will only do the setup on the head node, leaving the worker nodes not updated, which will cause the job running on the worker to have inconsistent environments vs the head node. This relates to the ray bug, as `ray up yaml_file --no-restart` will not transfer the new `setup.sh` to the worker nodes.

title: Public Bucket Checking + Error Handling
body:
Solves Zhanghao's Git Issue #295 

This PR does:
- [x] Can connect to public buckets
- [x] Better error handling if a bucket name is taken
- [x] Checks if bucket can be uploaded to; if not, handle error

## Tests

```
def test_public_bucket_aws():
    # Public Dataset: https://registry.opendata.aws/tcga/#usageexamples
    storage_1 = storage.Storage(name="tcga-2-open", source="s3://tcga-2-open")
    storage_2 = storage.Storage(name="tcga-2-open",
                                source="/Users/michaelluo/Downloads/temp/")
    try:
        # This should fail as you can't write to a public bucket
        storage_2.get_or_copy_to_s3()
    except Exception:
        pass
    storage_2.delete()
```

```
def test_public_bucket_gcp():
    # Public Dataset: https://registry.opendata.aws/tcga/#usageexamples
    storage_1 = storage.Storage(name='cloud-tpu-test-datasets',
                                source='gs://cloud-tpu-test-datasets')

    storage_2 = storage.Storage(name='cloud-tpu-test-datasets',
                                source='/Users/michaelluo/Downloads/temp/')
    try:
        # This should fail as you can't write to a public bucket
        storage_2.get_or_copy_to_gcs()
    except Exception:
        pass
    storage_2.delete()

```

title: Create daemon in new session; fix logging problem
body:
This PR is an attempt to fix the problem mentioned in #287, by creating the daemon for cleaning up child processes in a new session, instead of using `shell=True`, so that the daemon may not be killed when the session is killed by the OS.

Another change in this PR is to fix the unaligned logging caused by replacing the CRLF with LF (e.g. `sky exec debug -- 'for i in $(seq 1 120); do echo $i; sleep 1; done'` provided by @concretevitamin ). We now only replace the CRLF with LF when the output is logged to driver by ray.

Tested:
- [x] #276 
- [x] #275

title: Sky logging failed to detect when a task killed by OS
body:
Normally Sky will output the following messages to inform users when a task ends (no matter the task succeeds or fails)
```
I 02-08 21:53:05 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1324] 
I 02-08 21:53:05 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1324] Job ID: 12
I 02-08 21:53:05 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1324] To cancel the job:       sky cancel sky-68e0-weichiang 12
I 02-08 21:53:05 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1324] To stream the logs:      sky logs sky-68e0-weichiang 12
I 02-08 21:53:05 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1324] To view the job queue:   sky queue sky-68e0-weichiang
```
But when I was running a PyTorch DataParallel task, Sky's logging got stuck and stopped outputting anything.
```
(bert_sign pid=4878) checking if the adj is symmetric...                                              
(bert_sign pid=4878) Hop features: 100% 3/3 [01:31<00:00, 30.37s/it]                                  
(bert_sign pid=4878) Creating train_adj_t                                                             
(bert_sign pid=4878) Training:  50% 10/20 [00:04<00:04,  2.47it/s]
```
Turns out that the process was already killed by OS due to OOM. And we had to ssh login to find out.

After discussion with @Michaelvll, we think it might be the subprocess for cleaning things up  (https://github.com/concretevitamin/sky-experiments/blob/master/prototype/sky/skylet/log_lib.py#L108) is also killed by OS, leaving a bunch of zombie processes. Hence Sky logging wrongly assumed that the process is still running.

title: Fix output wrong order and overwriting problem
body: This PR is to solve the problem in #281. The previous problem is that if we have both print and tqdm in the program, the output will overwrite the last line of the console (due to the CRLF output of wandb), without new line, or in the wrong order.

title: stderr and stdout will not preserve the original order
body:
`tqdm` will print the output to stderr. If we have `tqdm` and print in the same program, the order of them will be messed up by either ray's logs_to_drive or our redirect_output function, sometimes making the output in the wrong order.

Also, when the end of line is replaced by CRLF (like wandb), all the output will overwrite the last line in the console, without new line.

Following yaml can reproduce the wrong order:
```yaml
resources:
  cloud: aws

setup: |
  echo "running setup"

run: |
  conda env list
  python3 -u -c "from tqdm import tqdm; import time; import sys; [time.sleep(1) for i in tqdm(range(12))]; print('done'); print('new')"
```

title: Fix the job cancelling for the pytorch data parallel
body: This PR solves the problem in #233. We will send the `SIGTERM` to the parent of the job process first to gracefully kill the program, then `SIGKILL` the process to make sure the program is cleaned up.

title: Fix laggy terminal after Ctrl+C from `sky exec` while streaming logs
body:
The problem is described in #246. The terminal will be very laggy after Ctrl+C during the `sky exec` is streaming the logs (`subprocess.run('sky logs cluster job_id')`). 

After some experiments, it seems that the problem does not exist when I ran `sky logs` directly in the terminal. Also, when the terminal becomes laggy, I will not able to do connect to the server with `sky queue`. Thus, I suspect that the `subprocess.run()` not correctly kill the ssh making the ssh still connected in the current session, so that makes the terminal laggy.

Main changes: Change the `subprocess.run('sky logs')` to directly run the statements in the `sky logs`.

-- Update --

By checking the `ps aux`, the process for the `sky logs` (`ssh -T ...`) still runs in the background, even after we kill the `sky exec` with ctrl+c. `subprocess.run` (and the `backend_utils.run`) is problematic for running commands that lasts a long time, as the process will still exist after ctrl+c. `shell=False` does not help for this.

TODO:
- [x] Find out the reason why the fix works

Tested:

- [x] ctrl+c while the tailing the logs in `sky exec`

title: Support multi-node tasks with any num_nodes smaller than the cluster
body:
This PR adds `$SKY_NODE_IPS` and `$SKY_NODE_ID` to the os environment before running multi-node commands, and also changes the python API for distributed training to support a dynamic number of nodes for training. #255 

Advantages:
1. We can now get the IP in runtime so that we can launch tasks with k nodes (using the IPs of the allocated nodes) on an n-node cluster (k<n). 
2. We can now run the distributed training with the yaml file.

Main changes:
1. export those two environment variables, $SKY_NODE_ID and $SKY_NODE_IPS, before running the multi-node commands.
2. Change the task.run dictionary design from `{ip: run_for_ip}` to `{node_id: run_for_node_id}`.
3. Replace `run(ip_list: List[str]) -> Dict[str, str]` function with `run(node_i: int, ip_list: List[str]) -> str`, so that the each node can generate the corresponding run command from the `run` function.

Tested / TODO:
- [x] `examples/env_check.yaml`
- [x] `examples/resnet_distributed_torch_app.py`
- [x] `examples/resnet_distributed_torch.yaml`
- [x] Update `examples/resnet_distributed_tf.py`
- [x] Run `examples/resnet_distributed_tf.py`/`examples/resnet_distributed_torch.py` (2 nodes) on a cluster with 4 nodes.

Update:
A way to run node-specific task, in yaml:
```yaml
run: |
  if (( SKY_NODE_ID == 0 )); then
    python main.py
  fi
  if (( SKY_NODE_ID > 4 )); then
    python test.py
  fi
```

In python API:
```python
def run_fn(node_rank: int, ip_list: List[str]) -> Optional[str]:
  # processing
  return f'python train.py --node {node_i} --master_addr {ip_list[0]}'
```

Future TODO:
1. Multi-node ray tune is not available in our code for both the original and current design, due to the placement group constraint.

title: ulimit get permission denied on AWS EC2
body:
The `ulimit` operation in the ray setup commands fails on AWS EC2. That will decrease the performance of ray as mentioned in the [ray doc](https://docs.ray.io/en/master/cluster/guide.html#system-configuration). The reason for failing is that the EC2 AMI has set the limitation of the files to open to a low value. ([reference](https://discuss.ray.io/t/setting-ulimits-on-ec2-instances/590))

There are two possible solutions:
1. https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11342167/how-to-increase-ulimit-on-amazon-ec2-instance
2. https://discuss.ray.io/t/setting-ulimits-on-ec2-instances/590

Note: We may need to be careful that some of the solutions may need a reboot, which costs too much time.

title: `sky launch` task with fewer num_nodes on existing cluster scales down the cluster
body:
`sky launch -c test launch.yaml` creates 4 nodes, but if we do `sky launch -c test task.yaml`, the cluster will be scaled down to 1 node. That may not be the expected behavior, since the user may only want to run the setup on the 4-node cluster. 

Proposed behavior: when launching a task with fewer num_nodes on an existing cluster, do not scale the cluster.

The two solutions I could think of all require API change:
1. Include the num_nodes in the `sky.Resources()`, so that the provision function can use the `num_nodes` in the `to_provision` to launch the cluster, rather than using the one in the task.
2. Let the provision function take the `num_nodes` argument.

```yaml
# launch.yaml
resources:
  cloud: aws
  accelerators:
    V100: 1
num_nodes: 4
```

```yaml
# task.yaml
resources:
  cloud: aws
  accelerators:
    V100: 0.5
num_nodes: 1

setup: # task specific setup
```

title: Sky storage naming problem
body: The name of S3 bucket is **globally unique**, even if it is created by another AWS user, so it is possible that the bucket name specified by the user has already been created by another AWS user. Our current implementation does not say anything about whether the bucket is available or not. It takes quite a long time to find out why I kept getting access denied for uploading local file to the cloud storage with the `sky.Storage` API.

title: Replace `task.run(ips)` with `task.run` and environment variable
body:
The `task.run(ips)` function is very useful for distributed training, but it blocks us from moving the yaml-based task taking ips in  `run` and also blocks us from supporting k-node task on the n-node cluster (1 < k < n) as the ips are decided before the actual scheduling.  Should we instead make the ips an environment variable-- `export SKY_NODE_IPS=(ip1 ip2 ip3)`?

For example, in the pytorch distributed case, we can have a simple yaml as the following:
```yaml
run: |
  python -m torch.distributed.launch --master_address=$SKY_NODE_IPS[0] main.py
```

title: Fix interactive node resource check when no cloud is specified

This should get merged after #216.

`resources.is_same_resources` will currently return `False` if a user re-uses a cluster where the default cloud is `None` and the launched resources are something like `AWS(p3.2xlarge)`, causing our resource check to fail for cases like the following:

To handle this, the cloud is inferred from the launched resources before running the resource check with user-specified resources.

title: Fix -a option for sky down
body: This is a quick fix for `-a` option for sky down. Otherwise, it will just skip termination.

title: Environment variables ignored in sky exec bash command
body:
I was expecting the task command to be `echo $TPU_NAME`.
```
sky ❯ sky exec t3 -- "echo $TPU_NAME"
Task from command: echo

Shared connection to 35.193.196.30 closed.
```

title: Ctrl+C during `sky exec` making the terminal keyboard input laggy in vscode
body: Not sure if `sky exec` is the actual reason, but every time I `Ctrl+C` during the `sky exec` is printing the logs, the keyboard input to the console will be very unresponding. Need more investigation on that.

title: Hide pip warning messages
body:
Older pip versions would generate various warning messages, and we want to hide them from users. One is known as https://stackoverflow.com/questions/67301493/what-does-this-deprecation-warning-mean-and-how-to-fix-it.

**Why not disable them with pip flags?**: Unfortunately, these flags generate warnings and errors when using new pip versions, because newer pip versions could drop these flags. Besides, pip could generate `WARNING: You are using pip version xxx; however, version yyy is available.` at any time. Another workaround could be using the `redirect_process_output` util, but I am not confident with pip warnings.

Close #218
